CO Temperature Humidity
//The gauges clicked
The Chart Optimal range 21-25
Red zone: below 10 or above 30 degrees way too cold or hot
Yellow zone: between 10-21 or 25-30 degrees, bit too hot or cold
Green zone: between 21-25 degrees, optimal
Description:
Red zone: Too hot or cold to concentrate and will impact the body in its ability to function and concentrate properly
Yellow zone: a bit too hot or cold, you will be able to feel a slight decrease in concentration and energy levels.
Green zone: Optimal and nothing to worry about.
Red zone: above 60% or less than 30% humidity, way too humid or dry
Yellow zone: between 30-45% or between 50-60% humidity, too humid or dry.
Green zone: between 45-50% humidity, optimal
Description:
Red zone: the indoor climate has reached levels that wont be optimal for you, it can mean that the room is either too humid or too dry. Can cause growth of mold, funguses, dust mites, and other pests. Mold contributes to a number of diseases and thrives in humid climates, generally above 60 percent. If the room continues to be in the red zone for an extended period of time try to increase your breaks from the room, or try to do something to fix it.
Yellow zone: it is either a bit too humid or dry. This wont have a huge affect on a healthy body, but people with asthma or respiratory diseases should not be in this room.
Green zone: Means that the humidity is perfect for optimal body function.
Red zone: above 90ppm, way too high co level CRITICAL
Yellow zone: between 70-90ppm, too high co level
Green zone: between 1-70ppm, optimal
Description:
Red zone: At sustained CO concentrations above 150 ppm, disorientation, unconsciousness, vomiting and death are possible.
Yellow zone: can increase risk of heart disease, cause headache, fatigue and nausea if it remains in this zone for an extended period of time, people with heart diseases might experience an increase in chest pain.
Green zone: Optimal and nothing to worry about.
